Jensen's formula

Show that the only entire function f(z)f\p{z}f(z) obeying both

∣f′(z)∣≤e∣z∣andf(n1+∣n∣)=0for alln∈Z\abs{f'\p{z}} \leq e^{\abs{z}} \quad\text{and}\quad f\p{\frac{n}{\sqrt{1 + \abs{n}}}} = 0 \quad\text{for all}\quad n \in \Z∣f′(z)∣≤e∣z∣andf(1+∣n∣​n​)=0for alln∈Z

is the zero function. Here ′'′ denotes differentiation.
Solution.

Suppose there exists such a function fff which is not the zero function. First, by the fundamental theorem of calculus,

f(z)=∫0zf′(z) dz+f(0)  ⟹  ∣f(z)∣≤∣z∣e∣z∣,f\p{z} = \int_0^z f'\p{z} \,\diff{z} + f\p{0} \implies \abs{f\p{z}} \leq \abs{z}e^{\abs{z}},f(z)=∫0z​f′(z)dz+f(0)⟹∣f(z)∣≤∣z∣e∣z∣,

since f(0)=0f\p{0} = 0f(0)=0. Since ex≥xe^x \geq xex≥x, we see ∣f(z)∣≤e2∣z∣\abs{f\p{z}} \leq e^{2\abs{z}}∣f(z)∣≤e2∣z∣.

Since fff is not identically zero, there exists n0∈Nn_0 \in \Nn0​∈N so that g(z)≔z−n0f(z)g\p{z} \coloneqq z^{-n_0}f\p{z}g(z):=z−n0​f(z) satisfies g(0)≠0g\p{0} \neq 0g(0)=0. The zeroes of fff cannot accumulate, so the zeroes are countable, so let {an}n\set{a_n}_n{an​}n​ be an enumeration of the zeroes of fff, which are precisely the zeroes of ggg.

First, notice that if nnn is large enough, say, n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N, then ∣n1+∣n∣∣≤n\abs{\frac{n}{\sqrt{1 + \abs{n}}}} \leq \sqrt{n}∣∣​1+∣n∣​n​∣∣​≤n​. Thus, for any M≥NM \geq NM≥N,

∑n=NMlog⁡∣n1+∣n∣∣≤∑n=NM12log⁡n≤12∫NMlog⁡x dx≤12∫1Mlog⁡x dx≤12(Mlog⁡M−M+1),\begin{aligned} \sum_{n=N}^M \log{\abs{\frac{n}{\sqrt{1 + \abs{n}}}}} &\leq \sum_{n=N}^M \frac{1}{2}\log{n} \\ &\leq \frac{1}{2} \int_N^M \log{x} \,\diff{x} \\ &\leq \frac{1}{2} \int_1^M \log{x} \,\diff{x} \\ &\leq \frac{1}{2}\p{M\log{M} - M + 1}, \end{aligned}n=N∑M​log∣∣​1+∣n∣​n​∣∣​​≤n=N∑M​21​logn≤21​∫NM​logxdx≤21​∫1M​logxdx≤21​(MlogM−M+1),​

where the second inequality comes from considering lower Riemann sums of log⁡x\log{x}logx on [N,M]\br{N, M}[N,M].

Let R>0R > 0R>0 be such that g(z)≠0g\p{z} \neq 0g(z)=0 on ∣z∣=R\abs{z} = R∣z∣=R. Then if ∣a∣<R\abs{a} < R∣a∣<R, we have log⁡∣aR∣<0\log{\abs{\frac{a}{R}}} < 0log∣∣​Ra​∣∣​<0, and so by Jensen's formula,

log⁡∣g(0)∣=12π∫02πlog⁡∣g(Reiθ)∣ dθ+∑∣an∣<Rlog⁡∣anR∣≤log⁡∣R−n0e2R∣+∑∣an∣<R;n≥Nlog⁡∣anR∣≤2R−n0log⁡R+∑n1+∣n∣<R;n≥Nlog⁡∣n∣R1+∣n∣≤2R−n0log⁡R+∑n<R;n≥Nlog⁡∣n∣R1+∣n∣=2R−n0log⁡R−∑n<Rlog⁡R+∑n<R;n≥Nlog⁡∣n∣1+∣n∣≤2R−n0log⁡R−⌊R2⌋log⁡R+12(Rlog⁡R−R+1).\begin{aligned} \log{\abs{g\p{0}}} &= \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \log{\abs{g\p{Re^{i\theta}}}} \,\diff\theta + \sum_{\abs{a_n} < R} \log{\abs{\frac{a_n}{R}}} \\ &\leq \log{\abs{R^{-n_0}e^{2R}}} + \sum_{\abs{a_n} < R; n \geq N} \log{\abs{\frac{a_n}{R}}} \\ &\leq 2R - n_0\log{R} + \sum_{\frac{n}{\sqrt{1+\abs{n}}} < R; n \geq N} \log{\frac{\abs{n}}{R\sqrt{1 + \abs{n}}}} \\ &\leq 2R - n_0\log{R} + \sum_{\sqrt{n} < R; n \geq N} \log{\frac{\abs{n}}{R\sqrt{1 + \abs{n}}}} \\ &= 2R - n_0\log{R} - \sum_{\sqrt{n} < R} \log{R} + \sum_{\sqrt{n} < R; n \geq N} \log{\frac{\abs{n}}{\sqrt{1 + \abs{n}}}} \\ &\leq 2R - n_0\log{R} - \floor{R^2} \log{R} + \frac{1}{2}\p{R\log{R} - R + 1}. \end{aligned}log∣g(0)∣​=2π1​∫02π​log∣∣​g(Reiθ)∣∣​dθ+∣an​∣<R∑​log∣∣​Ran​​∣∣​≤log∣∣​R−n0​e2R∣∣​+∣an​∣<R;n≥N∑​log∣∣​Ran​​∣∣​≤2R−n0​logR+1+∣n∣​n​<R;n≥N∑​logR1+∣n∣​∣n∣​≤2R−n0​logR+n​<R;n≥N∑​logR1+∣n∣​∣n∣​=2R−n0​logR−n​<R∑​logR+n​<R;n≥N∑​log1+∣n∣​∣n∣​≤2R−n0​logR−⌊R2⌋logR+21​(RlogR−R+1).​

Since ggg only has countably many zeroes, it follows that we may send R→∞R \to \inftyR→∞. But because the dominating term is −⌊R2⌋log⁡R-\floor{R^2}\log{R}−⌊R2⌋logR, we see log⁡∣g(0)∣≤−∞\log{\abs{g\p{0}}} \leq -\inftylog∣g(0)∣≤−∞, which is impossible as g(0)≠0g\p{0} \neq 0g(0)=0. Thus, fff must have been identically zero to begin with, which completes the proof.
